ygData.subject: Re: Evolving Coordinated Quadruped Gaits with the HyperNEAT Generative Encoding
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Jeff. Here is my opinion about the 4 hypothesis you suggested. ... Definitely true! :) While robots with 3+ legs are generally stable, biped robots have

Subject: Re: Evolving Coordinated Quadruped Gaits with the HyperNEAT Generative Encoding
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=ERZzaYlp-CZx2_-K4JjvlP_yPxEIerCNCzSn8zMKKuOYTJWWfvFVtIf3kg
X-Yahoo-Profile: petar_chervenski

Hi Jeff.

Here is my opinion about the 4 hypothesis you suggested. 

>1. Bi=
ped gaits are harder to evolve than quadruped gaits

Definitely true! :) Wh=
ile robots with 3+ legs are generally stable, 
biped robots have trouble ke=
eping their balance. My zero-g experiment 
with novelty search showed that =
getting an oscillation pattern that 
resembles a walking human is not a big=
 problem. But add gravity and it 
falls every time. Kind of frustrating :/ =

It is possible to get a good biped walking behavior with HyperNEAT or 
jus=
t regular NEAT, but it is hard to get results in practice.. Tyler 
Streeter=
 has done such experiments, in fact my own experiments were 
inspired by hi=
s work. 
It is interesting that NEAT performs well even in cases of only on=
e 
leg. Remember that NEAT Hopper demo? 
So I guess the failure of my exper=
iments is not because it is 
incredibly hard to evolve good biped walking g=
ait. It is hard indeed, 
but not that hard :) 

>2. The sine wave I provide=
d made it really easy to evolve periodic 
>gaits.

Yes, inputting just a si=
ne wave to the substrate is something clever 
and I never thought of that. =
I actually prefer leaky integrators 
because a CTRNN substrate made up by l=
eaky integrators doesn't need 
any inputs to make oscillations. It doesn't =
need inputs and timing at 
all. The time constant range in the leaky integr=
ator substrate becomes 
the thing that is as important as the period of the=
 sine wave in your 
system. 

>3. Leaky integrators hurt performance for so=
me reason.

Probably. The main reason behind why leaky integrator-based sub=
strates 
may perform worse is because not all networks are guaranteed to 
o=
scillate. Some just stabilize forever. Getting oscillation with leaky 
inte=
grator networks is like a small short-term challenge of its own. 
:) Inputt=
ing a sine wave explicitly makes the whole thing different. 
But there is a=
n interesting observation of leaky integrator substrates 
evolving with Hyp=
erNEAT. The neural activity itself appears 
distributed in a complexifying =
geometric pattern. The time constants 
and biases of the neurons are genera=
ted by a 2D/3D spatial CPPN. 

>4. I used a PID-based setup, where the targ=
et angle was the output of 
the
>neural net (and not the force to be applie=
d).

I used the same :) The outputs are all the target joint angle rescaled=
 
to min/max angle of the particular joint. But I tried applying forces 
an=
d even direct angular velocities. It is interesting, it has 
different dyna=
mics but the PID-based setup is closest to reality 
anyway :) 

Peter

--- =
In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> > Very interest=
ing paper! :)
> 
> Thanks. I'm glad you enjoyed it.
> 
> > It reminds me ab=
out the experiments I made with HyperNEAT for
> > controlling biped robots.=
 Did you try using leaky-integrator based
> > neurons for the substrate?
> =
> I found them very useful for generating
> > oscillation patterns. Substra=
tes of leaky integrators with tanh()
> > activation functions produce oscil=
lations much easier than others.
> > Hm.. I should really try with robots w=
ith 3 legs or more. Getting
> > biped walking with HyperNEAT is perhaps too=
 ambitious right now.
> 
> I have thought a lot about your biped experiment=
. I'd be really 
interested
> in hearing your opinion, and that of anyone e=
lse on this list, as to 
why
> your results were so different from mine. I =
found that it did not 
take that
> much tuning to get HyperNEAT to evolve r=
eally good quadruped gaits. 
But, as
> you note, it was much harder to evol=
ve gaits in your biped setup.
> 
> I can suggest a few hypotheses as to wha=
t explains the difference. 
These are
> not mutually exclusive, and it migh=
t not be the case that any one of 
them
> explains most of the difference, =
but instead that they add up to the
> difference. 
> 
> 1) Biped gaits are =
harder to evolve than quadruped gaits
> 2) The sine wave I provided made it=
 really easy to evolve periodic 
gaits.
> 3) Leaky integrators hurt perform=
ance for some reason
> 4) I used a PID-based setup, where the target angle =
was the output 
of the
> neural net (and not the force to be applied)
> 
> =
There are other differences of course, such as the inputs and the 
number o=
f
> hidden nodes. 
> 
> I'll make a few comments on each hypothesis.
> 
> 1=
) Biped gaits are harder to evolve than quadruped gaits.
> 
> This would be=
 easy to test by simply trying a biped with my setup.
> Unfortunately, I ha=
ve some other obligations that will prevent me 
from
> testing this anytime=
 soon, but if you (or anyone else) would like to 
give it
> a try, that wou=
ld be cool. I can send you the code I used. One would 
just
> need to chang=
e the quadruped into a biped. Alternately, you could 
try to
> mimic my set=
up in your "Ultimate NEAT" ;-).
> 
> I do have access to a huge computing c=
luster. So, if someone makes 
the code
> modifications to my setup (which I=
 know compiles on our cluster) and 
sends
> them to me, I can do a batch of=
 runs.
> 
> 2) The sine wave I provided made it really easy to evolve perio=
dic 
gaits
> 
> This would be an easy test. You could just plug a sine as a=
n input 
into your
> biped. Note: I found that the period of the sine wave =
made a huge
> difference. If I made it too fast or too slow, evolution basi=
cally 
ignored
> the signal. Within the range of periods that worked, I fou=
nd that I 
got
> different types of gaits with different period speeds. Wit=
h slower 
periods,
> I observed cool tortoise-like gaits with left-right sy=
mmetry. With 
medium
> periods, I got the gaits in the paper. With faster p=
eriods, I saw 
slightly
> more frantic versions of the gaits in the paper.
=
> 
> As a side note, I tried to evolve the period for a short while and 
it=
 was a
> miserable failure. I'd like to try that again, and would be 
inter=
ested to
> hear people's thoughts as to why it failed. Maybe I'll describe =
that 
attempt
> in another email. If someone out there is curious, let me k=
now and 
I'll send
> it out sooner rather than later.
> 
> 3) Leaky integra=
tors hurt performance for some reason.
> 
> I did not try leaky integrators=
. Did you ever try your setup without 
them?
> 
> I did not try them becaus=
e the default sigmoid neurons worked so 
well out of
> the box that I did n=
ot experiment with alternatives. Both Ken 
(during
> preliminary conversati=
ons about the paper) and one of the papers' 
reviewers
> asked about leaky =
integrators, so there is clearly some interest out 
there
> in seeing how l=
eaky integrators would compare to the neurons
> we used in the paper.
> 
> =
Do most of you feel leaky integrators would perform better? Why? I 
have
> =
never worked with them, nor do I know that much about them, so I 
don't hav=
e
> great instincts on this front. Is it possible that they could have 
mad=
e
> things worse in Petar's setup?
> 
> It would be cool to test them out i=
n my setup. Again, I won't be 
able to get
> to this in the near future so =
if someone out there wants to swap 
them in and
> give it a go, that would =
be interesting.
> 
> 4) I used a PID-based setup, where the target angle wa=
s the output 
of the
> neural net (and not the force to be applied).
> 
> I=
 could not figure out whether your setup did this as well. What 
were the
>=
 outputs in your system?
> ---------
> 
> Do you think any/all of these hyp=
otheses explain the difference in 
results?
> What other likely hypothesis =
am I missing (I am sure there are 
lots).
> 
> Thanks again for checking ou=
t the paper,
> Jeff
> 
> PS. Tripods would be fun. I also think adding feet=
 and a flexible 
torso
> would be interesting.
> 
> 
> 
> > 
> > Peter
> > =

> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >> He=
llo all-
> >> 
> >> Ever since I first understood HyperNEAT I have wanted t=
o see how 
it
> > would
> >> perform at controlling legged robots.
> >> 
> =
>> A paper I wrote on that subject was just accepted, so I can share 
it
> =
> with
> >> you now. 
> >> 
> >> A copy of the paper, and videos of the sim=
ulated robots, can be
> > obtained
> >> here:
> >> 
> >> 
> > 
http://devol=
ab.msu.edu/SupportDocs/EvolvingCoordinatedGaitsWithHyperNE
> > AT
> >> 
> >=
> 
> >> I hope you find it interesting. Please let me know what you 
think,=

> > or if you
> >> have any questions.
> >> 
> >> 
> >> Here is the cite a=
nd abstract:
> >> 
> >> Clune, J., Beckmann, B. E., Ofria, C., & Pennock, R=
. T.
> >> Evolving coordinated gaits with the HyperNEAT generative 
encodin=
g.
> >> 
> >> Proceedings of the IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Computing 
S=
pecial
> > Section
> >> on Evolutionary Robotics, 2009. Trondheim, Norway. =
To appear.
> >> 
> >> Legged robots show promise for complex mobility tasks=
, such as
> > navigating
> >> rough terrain, but the design of their contro=
l software is both
> > challenging
> >> and laborious. Traditional evolutio=
nary algorithms can produce 
these
> >> controllers, but require manual dec=
omposition or other problem
> >> simplification because conventionally-used=
 direct encodings have
> > trouble
> >> taking advantage of a problem's reg=
ularities and symmetries. Such
> > active
> >> intervention is time consumi=
ng, limits the range of potential
> > solutions, and
> >> requires the user=
 to possess a deep understanding of the 
problem's
> >> structure. This pap=
er demonstrates that HyperNEAT, a new and
> > promising
> >> generative enc=
oding for evolving neural networks, can evolve
> > quadruped gaits
> >> wit=
hout manually decomposing the problem. Analyses suggest that
> > HyperNEAT =
is
> >> successful because it employs a generative encoding that can more
>=
 > easily
> >> reuse phenotypic modules. It is also one of the first
> > ne=
uroevolutionary
> >> algorithms that exploits a problem's geometric symmetr=
ies, which 
may
> > aid its
> >> performance. We compare HyperNEAT to FT-NE=
AT, a direct encoding
> > control, and
> >> find that HyperNEAT is able to =
evolve impressive quadruped gaits 
and
> > vastly
> >> outperforms FT-NEAT.=
 Comparative analyses reveal that HyperNEAT
> > individuals
> >> are more h=
olistically affected by genetic operators, resulting in
> > better
> >> coo=
rdination of the quadruped's legs. Overall, the results 
suggest
> > that
>=
 >> HyperNEAT is a powerful algorithm for evolving control systems 
for
> >=
 complex,
> >> yet regular, devices, such as robots.
> >> 
> >>  
> >> 
> >=
> 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> Cheers,
> >> Jeff Clune
> >>

b, Michigan State University
